item.title: Hitman World of Assassination Will Receive Cross Progression Next Month
item.content:encoded:
Hitman: World of Assassination is getting a cross-progression update on February 3, 2026.

It has been a long time since we received an update for Hitman: World of Assassination. The last update we saw was a big one, as Eminem was announced as part of an Elusive Target Mission in the game. Now, the latest update doesn’t feature any content, but it’s still handy for players who play across different platforms.

Hitman: World of Assassination Cross Progression Details

As revealed in the new blog post, Hitman: World of Assassination’s Cross-Progression update will allow players to carry their in-game progression to any device they choose. Ahead of the update, a Steam patch will be released to ensure the feature works properly before it is released to the public.

While the Cross Progression feature is enabled, players can store and share their progress online across devices linked to the user’s IOI account. One device will serve as their primary progression profile, and all other platforms will be linked to it. While using cross-progression in Hitman: World of Assassination, Game License, DLC License, and DLC-based unlocks will not be shared, only the following data is shared across all platforms:

  • Experience 
  • Player Level 
  • Challenges 
  • Location Mastery 
  • Unlocks and Inventory 
  • Achievements / Trophies 
  • Freelancer Mode Progression 
  • Campaign Story Progress 

The DLC content should be owned on the platform they are playing, or else it won’t be accessible. Additionally, old save games from non-primary devices cannot be loaded via cross-progression; to load them, you will have to turn off the feature. Additionally, the Hitman 2 to Hitman 3 carryover process will be disabled from February 3, once cross-progression launches for Hitman: World of Assassination.

In other news, Hitman 4 was unofficially revealed by the IO Interactive CEO last month. What are your thoughts on Hitman: World of Assassination receiving cross-progression? Leave your thoughts down in the comments, and join the official Insider Gaming Discord server.

item.title: Russia’s ‘Call of Duty’ Could Cost 10 Billion Rubles, But The Government is Ready
item.content:encoded:
Russia is still preparing to make good on a promise to create a homegrown rival to Call of Duty. The dream is edging closer to reality, as government ministries signal they are prepared to offer immense financial support, tax breaks, and other incentives to any Russian studio willing to take on the gargantuan task.

The idea, which was first pushed by State Duma deputy Mikhail Delyagin, has now procured an official response from Russia’s Ministry of Digital Development. The numbers being lobbied are staggering, and the appropriate bodies could grant as much as 10 billion rubles ($128 million) to the right studio.

Russia’s Call of Duty Clone Could Become Reality

This isn’t the first time we’ve discussed Russia’s gaming aspirations in recent years. In 2024, Vladimir Putin ordered Russian tech titans to manufacture a range of home consoles that could eventually compete with the likes of Microsoft, Sony, and Nintendo. That front has gone somewhat quiet, but a new, software-based dream has emerged.

Russia wants to make a Call of Duty competitor.

According to an original report from Gazeta.Ru (and circulated by IXBT), the ministry confirmed that developers who propose a large-scale military shooter that echoes Activision’s Call of Duty could qualify for support from the Internet Development Institute, one of Russia’s key state-funded digital initiatives.

But how much support is the government offering?

Early estimates suggest that building a Russian AAA shooter on par with Call of Duty could cost as much as 10 billion rubles, or around $124 million. It would easily make it amongst the most expensive gaming-related projects in the nation’s history. It has been stressed before that ‘no domestic studio’ could accomplish the task without substantial government support.

Hence, the lobbying for a potentially enormous grant.

The quote from the Ministry reads:

If the IRI receives an application for the allocation of funding for the development of a game on a topic corresponding to that indicated in your letter, it will be considered in the established procedure within the framework of the current competitive mechanisms.

Beyond potential funding, the Ministry of Digital Development reminded Russian reporters that the government offers a ‘suite of financial benefits’ for IT companies innovating like this. That includes reduced corporate income tax rates, lowered insurance premiums, and partial VAT exemptions.

This news comes mere weeks after the State Duma, the ‘lower house’ of Russia’s parliament, called for an investigation into Call of Duty. By their claims, the franchise preaches Russophobia, by ‘always’ making the ‘bad guy’ a Russian individual or group.

It has been suggested that Russia’s Call of Duty would flip the script, allowing users to fight against American, British, and Ukrainian forces. It was dubbed a ‘strategically important’ game for Russia, but whether it would leave the confines of the country is another thing entirely.

Do you think Russia’s game developers could ever muster up the ability to create a Call of Duty rival? Let us know what you’re thinking on the Insider Gaming Discord server.

item.title: Xbox Game Pass January Wave 2 Features Death Stranding
item.content:encoded:
The wave 2 titles for Xbox Game Pass January 2026 have been revealed, and Death Stranding: Director’s Cut will be available to play from January 21.

It seems that Xbox Game Pass and PlayStation Plus have one matching title for January 2026, Resident Evil Village. It makes sense to release the game this month, as the next instalment to the series, Resident Evil Requiem, will be released on February 27. Check out the complete list of games added and games leaving Game Pass in January below.

Xbox Game Pass January 2026 Wave 2 Titles

There are 12 games that Xbox Game Pass subscribers can try out in January 2026. The biggest highlights from the list are Resident Evil Village, Death Stranding: Director’s Cut, and Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2. The likes of Death Stranding are usually available on PlayStation’s subscription service, but have now made it to Xbox Game Pass as well. This could be due to the partnership between Kojima Productions and Xbox for their upcoming title, OD.

Interested readers can check out all the games that will be added to Xbox Game Pass in January 2026 wave 2 below:

  • Resident Evil Village (Cloud, Console, and PC): Game Pass Ultimate, Premium, PC Game Pass
  • MIO: Memories in Orbit (Cloud, Handheld, PC, and Xbox Series X|S): Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass
  • Death Stranding Director’s Cut (Cloud, PC and Xbox Series X|S) – January 21: Game Pass Ultimate, Premium, PC Game Pass
  • RoadCraft (PC) – January 21: Game Pass Ultimate, Premium, PC Game Pass
  • Ninja Gaiden Ragebound (Cloud, PC, and Xbox Series X|S) – January 21: Game Pass Ultimate, Premium, PC Game Pass
  • The Talos Principle 2 (PC and Xbox Series X|S) – January 27: Game Pass Ultimate, Premium, PC Game Pass
  • Anno: Mutationem (Cloud, PC, and Console) – January 28: Game Pass Ultimate, Premium, PC Game Pass
  • Drop Duchy (Cloud, PC, and Console) – January 28: Game Pass Ultimate, Premium, PC Game Pass
  • MySims: Cozy Bundle (PC) – January 29: Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass
  • Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine II (Cloud, PC, and Xbox Series X|S) – January 29
  • Indika (Cloud, PC, and Xbox Series X|S) – February 2: Game Pass Ultimate, PC Game Pass
  • Final Fantasy II (Cloud, PC, and Xbox Series X|S) – February 3

Games leaving Game Pass in January 2026

Several games will be leaving the service on January 31, 2026. Check out the complete list below:

  • Shady Part of Me (Cloud, PC, and Console)Cataclismo (PC)
  • Starbound (Cloud, PC, and Console)
  • Lonely Mountains Snow Riders (Cloud, PC, and Console)
  • Paw Patrol World (Cloud, PC, and Console)
  • Citizen Sleeper 2 Starward Vector (Cloud, PC, and Console)
  • Orcs Must Die! Deathtrap (Cloud, PC, and Console)

In other news, Fable concept art has leaked ahead of the Xbox Developer Direct. Additionally, the ad-supported Xbox Cloud Gaming tier will reportedly release in 2026. item.title: Heartopia Codes: All Active Heartopia Codes & How to Redeem Them
item.content:encoded:
There is no shortage of things to do in Heartopia and, if you’re looking for a boost through progression, there are plenty of codes offering a variety of rewards to redeem.

Whether you’re just getting started in Heartopia or want to boost the currency at your disposal, Insider Gaming has details on all the active codes and how to redeem them.

All Active Heartopia Codes

Heartopia has an array of active codes to redeem to earn a tonne of rewards, including currency, crafting materials, food, and more.

Codes can only be claimed once, but provide a huge boost to your progression, along with handing you currency that can be used for the many gacha options available, which have a chance of handing you exclusive items and accessories.

The table below details all of the available Heartopia codes, and the rewards they provide.

How to Redeem Heartopia Codes

Heartopia codes are redeemed using the in-game menu and, unlike some other titles, the opption becomes available immediately after character creation.

As mentioned, codes can only be redeemed once per account, and some may have expiration dates, so it’s best to input the codes as soon as you find them.

Here’s a step-by-step guide on how to redeem codes in Heartopia.

  1. Click the Watch icon in the top-right corner of the screen.
  2. Scroll to the ‘Settings’ option and select it.
  3. Click on the ‘General’ tab.
  4. Select the ‘Redeem Code’ option, found in the bottom-right of the screen.
  5. Input the desired code and hit redeem.
  6. Collect your rewards from the mailbox outside your home.
